message.content:
We start by “marking” which rows affect fixed assets. In our list the “fixed assets” show up in two ways:

1. An “Initial” record that sets the opening fixed assets value.
  • This is the row with type “Fixed Assets” on 2023‑12‑31 with an amount of 5000000.0.

2. Any additional fixed asset purchase transactions. In our list these appear as rows whose type is “Fixed Assets Purchase” (their id begins with “FixedAsset20231231001”). In our file we find four such rows:
  a. A row with amount 73907.19 (asset “Production Line4”).
  b. A row with amount 171448.09 (asset, for example, “Storage Facilities5”).
  c. A row with amount 92277.65 (asset “Production Line6”).
  d. A row with amount 191303.24 (asset “Production Line7”).

To work out the ending fixed assets value we add these purchase amounts to the opening (initial) value.

Step‐by‐step:

• Sum of additional fixed asset additions =
 73907.19 + 171448.09 = 245355.28  
 245355.28 + 92277.65 = 337632.93  
 337632.93 + 191303.24 = 528936.17

• Then the ending value is:
 fixed assets end value = initial fixed assets (5000000.00) + additional (528936.17)
   = 5000000.00 + 528936.17 = 5528936.17

(No subtraction for depreciation is made here – as shown in the example that simply adds the purchase amounts.)

Thus the answer is:

────────────────────────────

{
  "solution": {
    "Fixed Assets Initial Value": "5000000.00",
    "Fixed Assets End Value": "5528936.17"
  }
}
